review.title: Propagation via Kernelization: The Vertex Cover Constraint
review.abstract: The technique of kernelization consists in extracting, from an instance of a problem, an essentially equivalent instance whose size is bounded in a parameter k. Besides being the basis for efficient param-eterized algorithms, this method also provides a wealth of information to reason about in the context of constraint programming. We study the use of kernelization for designing propagators through the example of the Vertex Cover constraint. Since the classic kernelization rules often correspond to dominance rather than consistency, we introduce the notion of "loss-less" kernel. While our preliminary experimental results show the potential of the approach, they also show some of its limits. In particular, this method is more effective for vertex covers of large and sparse graphs, as they tend to have, relatively, smaller kernels.

sections.heading: 1 Introduction
sections.text: This year it is more than ever before.

sections.heading: 2 Background and Notations
sections.text: An undirected graph is a child pair G = (V, E), where V is a series of vertices and E is a series of vertices, that is, pairs in V (V). We refer to the neighborhood N (V) = (V, E) of a vertice V, its closed neighborhood N + (V) = N (V) = N (V) and N (W) = (V) as delimited area N (V). The subgraph of G = (V, E), induced by a subset of vertices G, is referred to as G [W] = (W, 2W, E). An independent proposition is a set I V, whose coverage is not a pair of elements in E. A clique is a set C V, so that each pair of elements in C is in E. A clique cover T of a graph G = (V, E) is a collection of subordinate vertices in x.

sections.heading: 3 Kernelization as a Propagation Technique
sections.text: It is not the first time that the EU Commission has taken such a step.

sections.heading: 3.1 Standard Kernelization
sections.text: A problem is parameterized if each instance x is paired with a nonnegative integer k, and a parameterized problem is fixable (FPT) if it can be solved in time O (| x | O (1) f (k)) for any function f. A kernel algorithm takes as input a parameterized instance (x, k) and creates in polynomial time a parameterized instance (x, k) of the same problem, called the kernel, so that (i) (x, k) is satisfactory if (x, k) is satisfactory; (ii) | g (k) is satisfactory for any computable function g, and (iii) k "h" for any computable function h "(k) for h.While this formal definition does not guarantee that the kernel is a subinstance of (x, k).

sections.heading: 3.2 Loss-less Kernelization
sections.text: In the next definition, which we delineate from the cardinality of a minimal solution, this can only be formalized in the context of subset minimization problems, which speak for a subset S with a certain quality of a certain universe. sections.heading: 5 Experimental Evaluation
sections.text: We want to find a minimum vertex coverage, which can be expressed according to a partition of the same type, or a same client, or under the responsibility of the same service, etc., by being able to control the degree of balance to control the similarity of the problem to pure minimum vertex coverage. We used a series of graphs from the dimacs and snap repositories. For each graph G = (V, E) we set a VertexCover constraint at the specified variable S-V level (coincidentally) a balanced 4 partition {s1, s3} of vertex covers and we set the following constraints.

sections.heading: 6 Conclusion
sections.text: To design a propagation algorithm, we introduced the idea of a lossless kernel and outlined several ways to benefit from a small kernel. Our experimental evaluation of the VertexCover constraint shows that this approach is promising, with a "tolerance" of 1s and 1% nodes.
